headline: Opening Day in the Bronx
summary: See the scene at Yankee Stadium during the first game of the season for the New York Yankees.

headline: Deconstructing Buffett's Letter
summary: In an unusual personal announcement Wednesday, Warren Buffett said David Sokol, widely viewed as the leading contender to succeed him at the helm of Berkshire Hathaway, had resigned. See details on specific lines in Mr. Buffett's letter.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: SPDR Trust, Verizon Communications: Money Flow Leaders (SPY, VZ)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt for the week of March 28 - April 2, 2011.

headline: Renewable Energy Production, by State
summary: See how much energy each state produces from renewable sources, and a breakdown of these sources.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for March 31, 2011

headline: Devils 3, Isles 2
summary: New Jersey's playoff hopes are still alive—barely.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Sabres 1, Rangers 0
summary: Sabres backup goalie Enroth shuts down the Blueshirts.

headline: The Real First Day of Spring
summary: Images from the first games of the 2011 Major League Baseball season.

headline: Japan Disaster Pressures Asia Prices
summary: Japan's natural and nuclear disasters could worsen an inflation problem already looming over Asia's fast-growing economies, as supply-chain disruptions and increased Japanese demand for raw materials and untainted food boost pressure on prices.

headline: UAW Ranks Grew 6% Last Year
summary: The United Auto Workers said its membership grew 6% in 2010 amid a recovery in the U.S. auto industry and new organization efforts in such areas as casinos and universities.

headline: Morning News Roundup
summary: Here is a roundup of news from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Friday, April1, 2011. Deals India has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Euro Ticks Higher on Dollar
summary: The euro edged up against the dollar as the effect of recent hawkish rhetoric from Federal Reserve officials wore off, paring the dollar's recent gains.

headline: Report Cites Fannie, Freddie Executive Pay
summary: A federal watchdog criticized federal regulators' oversight of executive pay packages for top officials at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in a report published Thursday.

headline: Indonesia March Inflation Eases
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate eased in March on moderating basic food prices, the official Central Statistics Agency said.

headline: UPS to Install Cockpit Smoke-Protection
summary: UPS, after months of pressure from the union representing pilots, has decided to equip its entire fleet of cargo jets with smoke-protection devices designed to ensure that cockpit instruments remain visible in case of heavy smoke.

headline: Buffett Is Seen as Too Trusting
summary: Warren Buffett, the billionaire investor known for demanding truth and transparency, should have asked one of his own top deputies a few more questions, corporate-governance experts say.

headline: Australian Manufacturing Rocked by Currency Rise
summary: Australia's manufacturing sector contracted in March for the fourth time in five months, weighed down by the increasing cost of raw materials and the impact of a strong Australian dollar.

headline: Interior Department Ends Pact With Polu Kai Services
summary: The Interior Department said it ended a contract with a firm that said a proposed environmental rule could result in the loss of 7,000 coal mining jobs, leading Republicans to renew calls for an investigation.

headline: Options Trading Hit Record in March
summary: Stock-market volatility caused by news from Japan and North Africa helped make March the all-time busiest month in trading of U.S. listed options.

headline: Regulator Criticizes GOP's Fannie-Freddie Fixes
summary: The top regulator for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac criticized Republican proposals to address the mortgage titans' future as either unnecessary or counterproductive.

headline: Big Banks Back 'Say on Pay'
summary: Goldman Sachs Group Inc., J.P. Morgan Chase & Co., Morgan Stanley and other financial firms are expected to recommend in coming proxy filings that shareholders get an annual vote on executive-pay practices, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Schneider to Export Digilink Products
summary: Smartlink Network Systems's 5.03 billion rupee sale of its Digilink unit was motivated by the lack of growth opportunities in the business, the company's chairman said.

headline: Laid to Rest: Geraldine Ferraro, 1935-2011
summary: One-time U.S. vice-presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro's funeral drew hundreds of mourners, including Bill Clinton, Walter Mondale, Michael Bloomberg and other dignitaries.

headline: Korean Data May Prompt BOK Rate Rise
summary: South Korea ran a higher-than-expected trade surplus in March, while its consumer price inflation surged to a 29-month high, signaling further monetary policy tightening to prevent the economy from overheating.

headline: U.K., Oil Producers to Discuss Tax Increase
summary: Major U.K. oil and gas producers said they will directly lobby U.K. Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne to mitigate the effects of a large tax increase on the industry.

headline: Michael Auslin: Lead Japan to Recovery, Mr. Kan
summary: The prime minister's lack of engagement or a plan for growth is getting low marks.

headline: Dim Sum on Demand
summary: Dim sum on demand is Nom Wah Tea Parlor's specialty, but its classic mid-century interior is what gives this Chinatown restaurant an undeniable charm.

headline: Witness Says She Saw Bonds Get Injection
summary: Barry Bonds's former personal shopper testified Thursday that in 2002 she saw the slugger's personal trainer give him an injection in his navel.

headline: Options Players Gird for Higher Oil Prices and Inflation
summary: Investors are paying options premiums that suggest looming geopolitical and inflation concerns, with traders making a bullish play oil-related options and a protective move in the consumer-staples sector

headline: Spanish Style -- Photos
summary: Tour Spanish Mediterranean-style homes in California, Arizona and Florida.

headline: Private Properties -- Photos
summary: A Las Vegas estate with 73,000 square feet of living space across eight buildings -- including 18 bedrooms and 36 bathrooms -- has seen its price lowered by a third. Also, private investor Henri Wedell has listed a ranch in Argentina.

headline: DJIA Ends Big Quarter With Loss
summary: Stocks edged lower in a late slide on Thursday but still managed to finish up for the third consecutive quarter.

headline: Toyota to Boost U.S. Prices
summary: Toyota Motor will raise U.S. prices on most of its vehicles by up to 2.2% beginning in May.

headline: Ally Financial Likely to Raise $5 Billion
summary: Ally Financial likely will allow the U.S. government to sell about $5 billion of its current stake in the auto lender by this summer, according to people close to the deal.

headline: Judge Says Medtronic Device Doesn't Infringe Patents
summary: A type of defibrillator sold by Medtronic doesn't infringe patents held by rival Boston Scientific, a federal judge in Delaware ruled.

headline: Cash Flows Into Money-Market Funds
summary: Assets in money-market funds jumped $3.94 billion in the week ended Wednesday, as sharp inflows into institutional assets more than offset outflows from retail funds.

headline: Magna's Stronach to Step Down as Chairman
summary: Magna International founder Frank Stronach is stepping down as chairman but will remain on the board of the giant auto-parts maker.

headline: Global Trade Facing Headwinds
summary: Global trade as a share of gross domestic product, which had expanded rapidly for 20 years before the crisis, may stagnate, with worrying implications.

headline: Dollar Trims Losses Against Euro
summary: A signal that the Federal Reserve may finally be preparing to raise rates from record lows to combat inflation boosted the dollar against its chief rival, pulling the euro off near five-month highs.

headline: Venezuela May Pay $2.5 Billion in Exxon, Conoco Arbitration
summary: Venezuela could pay around $2.5 billion to Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips for assets that were expropriated by the government nearly four years ago, according to the oil ministry.

headline: A Rainy Day for a Tea Party
summary: Supporters of the conservative political movement gathered Thursday in Washington to urge GOP leaders in the House to push forward with cuts to the federal budget.

headline: Municipal-Bond Issuance Lowest Since 2000
summary: Municipal-bond issuance in the first quarter is set to be the lowest quarterly volume in more than a decade after a surge of borrowing late last year siphoned off supply and as government borrowers strive to get their budgets in order.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended March 25 amounted to 28.1% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 1.79 billion shares, or 504.6 million program shares traded per day.

headline: India's MCX Files Draft IPO Prospectus
summary: The IPO in the country's largest commodity exchange by trade value will consist of 6.4 million shares, all from existing shareholders, according to the prospectus. A proposed price range and timeline hasn't been decided.

headline: Luby's, Synthesis Energy Systems: Biggest Price Gainers (LUB, SYMX)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Colombia 'Optimistic' on U.S. Trade Deal
summary: Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos told U.S. business leaders in Bogotá Wednesday that he has "reasons to be optimistic" that a deal on a long-stalled U.S.-Colombia trade pact is in the offing.

headline: Gold Settles at New Record
summary: Comex gold futures settled at a record on worries about Europe's financial system and forecasts for higher gold demand from India. The contract for April delivery rose 2.1% to $1,438.90 per troy ounce.

headline: Fed Gives First Glimpse at Discount-Window Lending
summary: The Fed revealed which financial institutions came to it directly for money up until March 1, 2010. Washington Mutual took billions in the week before it failed, and foreign banks were big borrowers.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, militiamen patrol the capital of Ivory Coast, a man mourns his father after a suicide attack in Pakistan, U.S. federal guidelines now allow miniature horses as guide animals, and more.

headline: Oil Settles at 2½-Year High
summary: Oil futures settled at $106.72 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, their highest level in 2½ years, amid fears of prolonged conflict in the Middle East.

headline: High Grain Prices Here to Stay
summary: U.S. farmers are expected to grow more corn this year, but stockpiles have shrunk more than expected. That will keep the pressure on food costs.

headline: Behind the Window: Banks' Crisis-Era Borrowings
summary: The Fed released troves of documents offering details about which banks borrowed money from the discount window from August 2007 through March 2010. Here are some of the banks and their moves.

headline: Yale Plans Joint Campus in Singapore
summary: Yale University and the National University of Singapore said they will establish a joint campus in Singapore in 2013 as part of a much-debated effort to expand Western-style liberal-arts education in Asia.

headline: Europe M&A Activity Slowly Revives
summary: Merger-and-acquisition activity in Europe continued to awaken from a long slumber in the first quarter, though the pace of recovery remains slow amid lingering worries over the health of government finances in the region and other threats to the global economy.

headline: Agriculture Futures Surge On Crop Reports
summary: Grain futures jumped after U.S. officials reported declines in inventories. The gains came despite a separate report predicting growers will increase their plantings of most crops, as futures traders and analysts worried over the weather.

headline: Pfizer, Glaxo Disclose Fees to U.S. Doctors
summary: Pfizer paid $177 million and GlaxoSmithKline paid $85 million during 2010 to U.S. doctors and institutions for their work on clinical trials, consulting, speaking and other items.

headline: Treasury to Sell $86 Billion of Bills Next Week
summary: The Treasury Department plans to sell $86 billion of bills next week, including $62 billion of three- and six-month bills, and $24 billion of 52-week bills.

headline: Bombardier Jet Orders Climb
summary: Bombardier's fourth-quarter earnings jumped 82% as business-jet orders picked up substantially during the period.

headline: ConocoPhillips CEO Compensation Rises 25%
summary: ConocoPhillips Chief Executive Jim Mulva received about $17.9 million in total compensation in 2010, a 25% increase from the previous year.

headline: Shell, Petrofac Sign Deal to Upgrade Iraqi Oil Field
summary: Royal Dutch Shell and its partners signed Thursday a $200 million deal with U.K.-based oil- and gas-services company Petrofac to supply early-production units for the development of the supergiant Majnoon oil field in southern Iraq.

headline: Wintershall Sees Increasing Profits
summary: The German crude-oil and natural-gas producer said Thursday it expects to increase sales and profits in 2011 and will continue to pursue exploration and production projects in the Middle East.

headline: Terra Firma Buys Italian Solar Company
summary: Guy Hands's Terra Firma said it bought Italian solar-energy company Rete Rinnovabile S.r.l. in a deal worth around €641 million ($905.5 million), the largest-ever solar-generation acquisition in Europe.

headline: Sokol: In and Out
summary: David Sokol, widely seen as the leading contender to succeed billionaire Warren Buffett at the helm of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., resigned Wednesday amid surprising revelations about his purchase of shares of Lubrizol, a company Berkshire has agreed to acquire. See Lubrizol's stock price and a timeline of events.

headline: Sands China Faces Probe
summary: A Las Vegas Sands unit said it is being investigated by Hong Kong's securities regulator, adding to a list of U.S. federal and state authority probes of the casino company.

headline: Europe's Stocks Fall
summary: European markets fell, as concerns over the results of Irish banks' stress tests prompted investors to sell financial shares across the region.

headline: Italy Weighs Fund to Protect Strategic Firms
summary: The Italian government is weighing whether and how to set up a financial vehicle that would allow the state to make targeted strategic investments to protect Italian companies from foreign predators.

headline: Washington in Bloom
summary: It's the height of cherry blossom season in the nation's capital.

headline: Belarus Rejects Sharp Devaluation
summary: Belarus's central bank ruled out a sharp devaluation of the country's currency, even as the IMF and a top-level government official said such a move may be needed.

headline: Penney CEO's Pay Rises
summary: J.C. Penney chief Myron Ullman received total compensation of $13 million for 2010, up about 50% from the previous year.

headline: Taylor Wimpey Struggles to Climb Another Rung
summary: Until the U.K. housing market picks up, the home builder will find it tough going.

headline: Author of Enchanting Children's Books Tackled Larger Themes
summary: English novelist Diana Wynne Jones, who wrote about a boy facing the challenges of mastering magic at school some 20 years before Harry Potter arrived, died of lung cancer at the age of 76.

headline: John Lee: Why Taiwan Will Fail
summary: Taipei has a plan to make a virtue out of the necessity of greater integration. But Beijing will demand reunification and time is on its side.

headline: Sweden Backs More Saab Loans
summary: Spyker Cars won backing from the Swedish government to enable it to draw down fresh funding for its Saab Automobile unit as another supplier to the car maker halted deliveries in a dispute over payments.

headline: Hedge Funds Go Long on Japanese Equity
summary: Hedge funds have turned positive on Japanese equities for the first time since November, according to Société Générale.

headline: H&M Earnings Drop  As Cotton Costs Rise
summary: Hennes & Mauritz said its net profit in the first quarter fell 30% from a year earlier as the fashion retailer stuck with its pricing even as its costs jumped.

headline: Korean Air, Asiana Incidents Detailed
summary: Japanese air-safety investigators released reports about a pair of hazardous in-flight incidents involving Korea's two largest airlines. The findings reveal significant mechanical malfunctions and pilot mistakes.

headline: Prada Steps Closer to Hong Kong IPO
summary: Italian fashion house Prada SpA has filed a request to list its shares on the the Hong Kong Stock Exchange and is planning to sell a 20% stake in the family-run company during the initial public offering.

headline: Foreign Minister Flees Libya
summary: The resignation of Libya's foreign minister Moussa Koussa -- who arrived Wednesday in Britain -- marks the biggest diplomatic setback for Col. Moammar Gadhafi since the start of the Libyan uprising, and raises hopes among allied officials that other members of the leader's close circle may follow suit.

headline: China Merchants Bank Posts 41% Rise In Net Profit
summary: China Merchants Bank, the country's sixth-largest lender by assets, reported a 41% rise in 2010 net profit as interest margins recovered.

headline: Bajaj on Track With Low Cost Car
summary: Bajaj Auto is ready with a prototype of a low-cost small car to rival Tata Motors' Nano, the cheapest car in the world, and will soon show it to its partners in the project, Renault and Nissan Motor.

headline: NCR Adds DVD Kiosks
summary: NCR won a contract to place its Blockbuster Express movie rental kiosks in 309 RaceTrac convenience stores throughout the Southeast.

headline: India Extends Stockholding Curbs
summary: India has extended stockholding curbs on the quantity of sugar, edible oils and oilseed stocks that traders and wholesale dealers can hold by six months to Sept. 30 to keep a lid on food prices.

headline: Government, Banks Meet on Mortgage Deal
summary: State and federal officials and five of the nation's largest banks met for the first time Wednesday to discuss the terms of a settlement agreement designed to correct abuses in the mortgage industry.

headline: Kodak CEO's Pay Drops
summary: Kodak said CEO Antonio Perez received total compensation valued at $5.7 million in 2010, less than half of what he earned a year earlier as he missed the company's performance targets.

headline: IndiGo Orders 300 Pratt & Whitney Engines
summary: Calling it the company's largest single order in the past 50 years, Pratt & Whitney announced an order for 300 new Geared Turbofan engines from Indian low-cost carrier IndiGo. The new engines will power 150 Airbus A320 jets IndiGo ordered in January.

headline: Shallow Gains for Lake Mead
summary: Lake Mead is rising for only the second time since the Southwest entered a debilitating drought 12 years ago, thanks to heavy rain and snow this winter. But the new rush of water is nowhere near enough to make up for the dozen-year deficit.

headline: Big Buys
summary: Russian investor Yuri Milner has bought a French chateau-style mansion in Silicon Valley for $100 million. The deal is thought to be the priciest for a U.S. single-family home. Take a look at some other major transactions.

headline: U.K. to Boost Currency Reserves
summary: The U.K. government's plans to boost its foreign-exchange reserves by £6 billion ($9.65 billion) a year are designed to meet overseas commitments and not to manage the pound's exchange rate, the U.K. Treasury said.

headline: India Orders More Boeing Maritime Planes
summary: India's federal government has approved the purchase of four more P-8I long-range maritime patrol and anti-submarine warfare aircraft from Boeing Co., a senior executive at the U.S. defense contractor said.

headline: New York State Passes Budget
summary: A day ahead of the deadline, New York adopted a $132.5 billion budget, giving Gov. Andrew Cuomo his most significant victory since he took office in January.

headline: Japan's Manufacturing Plummets
summary: Japanese manufacturing activity slowed in March at its sharpest pace on record, following the earthquake and tsunami earlier in the month.

headline: Bali's Tourist Challenge
summary: Natural beauty and a gentle vibe have made the Indonesian island of Bali a magnet for visitors—bringing prosperity for some but also driving traffic jams, sprawl, deforestation and crime.

headline: GE-Whizzes: Everyone's Looking for Edge on Taxes
summary: GE isn't the only corporate giant striving to pay as little as possible under the tax code. Wall Street firms, battered by losses during the financial crisis, wrote down their tax bills using a variety of methods and claimed benefits against other tax bills.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: Japanese government bond yields edged up on the final day of the country's fiscal year, as a late-afternoon rally in share prices dented demand for safe-haven assets.

headline: Currency Moves Highlight Global Divide
summary: South Korea and Malaysia were believed to have intervened to slow the rise of their currencies Thursday, as China set the yuan at a record high and the U.S. and France called for more exchange-rate flexibility—code for wanting Beijing to let its currency rise faster.

headline: MCX Files IPO Prospectus
summary: India's Multi Commodity Exchange, the country's largest commodity bourse by trade value, has filed a draft prospectus for an initial public offering with the capital markets regulator.

headline: Jury Finds Abbott Broke Glaxo Pact
summary: A California jury found Abbott Labs breached a license agreement with GlaxoSmithKline, awarding damages to Glaxo, but found Abbott didn't violate antitrust laws.

headline: U.K. House Prices on Shaky Foundations
summary: U.K. house prices rose unexpectedly for a second consecutive month in March, but weak mortgage-lending figures and a Bank of England policy maker's forecasts of higher mortgage rates suggest the economist forecast is overcast.

headline: Indian Shares Extend Gains
summary: Indian shares continued their strong run for the eighth straight session - the longest market rally in two years - led by gains in technology shares amid choppy trade due to the expiry of March derivatives.

headline: Starbucks Hopes for India JV
summary: Starbucks said it hopes to soon move forward in its partnership with India's Tata Coffee.

headline: Baidu to Transfer Merchants Off Youa
summary: Chinese online search provider Baidu will transfer merchants from its Youa e-commerce service to e-commerce website Yaodian100.com and to a website run by Baidu's joint venture with Japan's Rakuten.

headline: India Court Extends Custody of Ex-Telecom Minister
summary: An Indian court extended the judicial custody of former telecom minister Andimuthu Raja, two of his former aides and a corporate executive until April 2 in a case related to irregularities in allotting telecom licenses and bandwidth in 2008.

headline: Acid Test for Swiss Big-Bank Overhaul
summary: Proposals to toughen regulations on Swiss banking giants UBS and Credit Suisse Group face a severe test as the country moves toward elections later this year, according to experts.

headline: Rate Worries Weigh on Shanghai Shares
summary: Most Asian stock markets were modestly higher but caution ruled ahead of U.S. jobs data. China's shares were hurt by renewed concerns about further monetary tightening from Beijing, and Shanghai fell 0.9%.

headline: German Jobless Rate Falls to Record Low
summary: Germany's labor market improved significantly in March and unemployment declined by more than expected, propelled by the country's economic upswing.

headline: L&T Sells Stake in Equipment JV
summary: Larsen & Toubro said it has exited its joint venture L&T-Case Equipment by selling its stake to partner, CNH Global. The companies didn't reveal what CNH paid for the stake.

headline: India Food Inflation Eases Again
summary: Food inflation in India decelerated in the week to March 19 to 9.5% year-on-year as vegetable prices declined, calming worries that the rise reported last week would reignite price pressures in the economy.

headline: Delayed Returns
summary: Despite $150 billion worth of delayed infrastructure projects, investors remain bullish and have evolved strategies to mitigate some of the risk.

headline: Zurich Financial Books $500 Million Loss on Natural Disasters
summary: Zurich Financial Services said it expects combined losses from recent catastrophes in the Asia-Pacific region to amount to $500 million, which it will book against first-quarter earnings.

headline: Vietnam Looks to Slash Public Spending
summary: Vietnam is expected to cut public investment by $2.4 billion or 7.4% this year, the central bank said, in its latest attempt to restore economic stability.

headline: Pledging Shares for Capital
summary: The trend of promoters of Indian companies pledging shares to raise money is back. Sometimes, parent companies are pledging shares of smaller group firms to raise debt to fund the former's growth, acquisition and even buyback of shares.

headline: Tulip's Data Center Unit Interests Buyers
summary: Tulip Telecom has received bids from 25 to30 companies, mostly foreign firms, to buy up to 30% stake in its wholly owned data center unit. The company wants to raise $60 million for further expansion.

headline: DoCoMo Ups Investment in Tata Venture
summary: Japanese telecom firm NTT DoCoMo will make an additional investment of 8 billion rupees, or $179 million, in India's Tata Teleservices via a rights issue, part of the Japanese firm's strategy to expand its presence in the country.

headline: Honeywell to Build Turbocharger Plant in Slovakia
summary: Honeywell International confirmed it will build a new turbocharger manufacturing plant in Presov, Slovakia, amid growing demand by auto makers for the fuel-efficiency boosting technology.

headline: Foxconn Swings to Loss
summary: Contract handset maker Foxconn International said it swung to a full-year net loss on higher production costs and falling product prices, and the company said it must urgently step up efforts to cut costs and secure new customers.

headline: Taylor Wimpey Sells North American Operations
summary: U.K. home builder Taylor Wimpey said it is selling its North American operations for $957 million as it refocuses on the U.K. property market.

headline: EU Pins Down 9 Indicators to Gauge Imbalances
summary: Senior European government officials have drawn up a list of nine key indicators that should be used to signal whether a country is developing potentially dangerous economic imbalances.

headline: Sales Data Push Aussie to Another High
summary: Australian consumers in February shrugged off the effects of some of the nation's worst natural disasters and returned to the high street, boosting retail sales beyond economists expectations.

headline: SK Telecom Considers Blockbuster Bid
summary: South Korea's SK Telecom is considering a bid for U.S. movie-rental chain Blockbuster, which filed for bankruptcy court protection last year.

headline: Smartlink Board OKs Cable Unit Sale
summary: India's Smartlink Network Systems' board has approved the sale of the company's structured cabling business to a unit of Schneider Electric for 5.03 billion rupees in cash.

headline: Suit Against SAC Capital's Cohen Dismissed
summary: The former wife of SAC Capital Advisors founder Steven A. Cohen can't pursue a lawsuit against the hedge-fund manager, a judge has ruled.

headline: Jamie Whyte: Adults of the World, Unite!
summary: The 'right' amount of alcohol is the amount we consume voluntarily.

headline: Has Baseball's Moment Passed?
summary: The national pastime is struggling with a phenomenon that could prove more destructive than steroids or dwindling World Series ratings. Too many kids are choosing to play other sports.

headline: China Executes Three Filipinos
summary: China executed three convicted Filipino drug couriers, triggering grief and anger in the Philippines that threatened to undermine an already tense relationship between the two countries.

headline: Search for High-Growth Media Leads to Google
summary: As media companies go, Google is a supercharged growth stock. It's about time investors started treating it as such.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of March 31, 2011

headline: Heavyweight Currencies Slug It Out in Nanjing
summary: The meeting of G-20 ministers over the role of the dollar in the international financial system isn't likely to yield a decision on what should be the world's reserve currency. That means the dollar, yuan and euro will battle for the title.

headline: 'Melo and a Late Win, Again
summary: As two big acquisitions squared off in the cross-river rivalry, Carmelo Anthony showed why he was the top trade target for both teams.

headline: Outsmart Airlines to Get Best Seat
summary: With seat layouts and ratings for 720 different airplanes flown by 100 different airlines, SeatGuru.com has become the authoritative source for cabin information.

headline: Google Loses Ground in China
summary: A year after Google moved its search services out of China in a feud with Beijing, the Internet giant is struggling to maintain traction on a range of businesses in the country.

headline: TARP Watchdog Spars Over 'Too Big to Fail'
summary: In his final day on the job, a federal bailout watchdog squabbled publicly with a Treasury official over the legacy of the $700 billion Troubled Asset Relief Program as both individuals testified before lawmakers.

headline: Gadhafi Push Tests Allies
summary: Forces loyal to Gadhafi continued to push rebels out of positions along coastal oil towns, further delaying the rebel drive on Tripoli and testing the limits of the coalition air strikes at a time when the alliance is considering arming Gadhafi's opponents.

headline: Paulson-Led Group Pushes Lehman Plan
summary: A group of bondholders including Paulson & Co. wants a bankruptcy judge to consider its competing reorganization plan for Lehman Brothers on the same timetable as the plan Lehman filed.

headline: Edano: Japan to Welcome Further Nuclear Help
summary: Japan has improved its ability to tap into the knowledge of nuclear experts from around the world and plans to use the foreign help more in addressing its nuclear crisis, the government's chief spokesman, Yukio Edano, said.

headline: It's Another Kind of 'Early Music'
summary: None

headline: Radiation Traces Found in U.S. Milk
summary: The U.S. government said that traces of radiation have been found in milk in Washington state, but said the amounts are well below levels of public health concern.

headline: Is That a Bear or a Bull in the Corn Field?
summary: Ahead of the Tape:  Crop prices have declined recently, but they may not remain under pressure for too long.

headline: The Knicks Have a Hole in the Middle
summary: In the 20 games the Knicks have played since their February trade for Carmelo Anthony, four players have started at center, and none has been able to lay claim to the position.

headline: Billingsley Shows Love for Los Angeles
summary: Chad Billingsley gives the Los Angeles Dodgers a discount. Plus, India beats Pakistan at the Cricket World Cup and the swag behind VCU's swagger.

headline: Marian L. Tupy: Foreign Aid Isn't the Answer
summary: Africa exemplifies how aids spoils economic growth and discourages democratic reform.

headline: From Nixon to Obama
summary: Bad energy speeches are a Presidential tradition.

headline: CIA Operatives Are Aiding Rebels
summary: The Central Intelligence Agency has placed covert operatives on the ground in parts of Libya, feeding intelligence on ground targets to the U.S. military and coalition forces for airstrikes and reaching out to rebels aligned against Col. Moammar Gadhafi.

headline: Cities Seek to Turn Over Policing Role
summary: Some Bay Area cities struggling with declining revenue are taking steps to merge police operations or outsource the agencies to county sheriff departments.

headline: Tip of the day
summary: When the PGA Tour's Houston Open was moved to the week before the Masters in 2006, tournament officials drew up a radical strategy to attract the world's best players. They moved Augusta National to the middle of Texas.

headline: Minkow Pleads Guilty in Fraud Case
summary: Former stock-fraud investigator Barry Minkow pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit securities fraud.

headline: Duda Ready to Replace Bay
summary: Mets general manager Sandy Alderson said Lucas Duda would take Bay's roster spot if they put him on the disabled list.

headline: Building Jazz Its Own Home
summary: In May, SFJazz will break ground on the first freestanding structure designed and named for jazz. Larry Blumenfeld has a Cultural Conversation with the organization's visionary artistic director, Randall Kline.
